**Summary:**
- Dog walking is getting paid to take your client’s dog for a walk
- You don’t need any up-front investment to get started
- You need to understand the basics of dealing with dogs
- Be prepared to go out in all weather

**Action steps:**
- Understand how you can make money from dog walking

How much do you need to start dog walking?

A $20-$30
B $0 -
C $0-$5

**Summary:**
- You don’t need any qualifications to get started but it can make you stand out
- You can decide to walk multiple dogs at once but make sure you can handle them all
- The easiest way to get your first clients is to ask people you already know who have dogs
- Once you’ve exhausted everyone you know, you can go door-to-door or utilize Facebook

**Action steps:**
 - Reach out to family and friends and offer to walk their dogs

**Summary:**
- You can charge $10-$30 depending on the demand in your area
- You can get paid in cash, bank transfer or payment processors
- Writing a simple contract can set out the expectations on each side from the start

Contract example: [click here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Kgc8iCZBdQunjWaRvTze5TJ-SqI6hyVAghgLM8OjYdk/edit?usp=sharing)

**Action steps:**
- Apply the steps and start your dog-walking business

**YOUR ACTION STEPS ** 

**Step 1: Ask your neighbors, family, or friends to walk their dog(s)**
> - The fastest way to get new clients for dog walking is to simply ask people you already know.
> - Ask your neighbors, family, or friends if you can walk their dog.
> - Chances are you already know their dog so it will be easy to build up your experience with a dog you're familiar with.

**Step 2: Walk the dogs**
> - Once you've found someone willing to let you walk their dog, next you have to actually do it.
> - Arrange a time to collect the dog from the owner's house - make sure you're on time.

**Step 3: Profit**
> - Once the walk is complete, ask for payment from your client.
> - If you're getting paid cash, you can collect it upon returning the dog.
> - If you make an agreement with your client for regular walks, you could set up a monthly or weekly retainer.

**Step 4: Expand your client base**
> - Once you've exhausted your list of people you know and you'd like to take on more work, start new outreach methods.
> - Go through the Harness Your Facebook course and join local groups to promote your services.
> - Design and print pamphlets to distribute in your area advertising your services.

**Step 5: Repeat**
> - Dogs need walks regularly so you can turn your existing clients into recurring clients by continuing to offer your services.
> - If you can take on more work, repeat the steps to take on more clients.

What are some methods we recommend on finding more customers?

A Google, Youtube and TikTok
B Your local small business and door-knocking
C Neighbors & Family, Facebook and Pamphlets
